values: So I finally snagged an invitation code for AO3 and have now started moving some of my old fic across, and have posted 3 chapters of my current Veronica Mars WIP. This weekend I finished revising chapters 14-19 of the novel (11 to go), but kept getting distracted by my LoVe fix-it fic. Hence why there's now 3 chapters on public display. Ever since I donated to the Kickstarter I've been consuming VM fic like crack. Anyone out there have any good long plotty recs to throw my way?

GOOD NEWS - I hit the 50K for NaNoWriMo 5 days early

BAD NEWS - the story still has a good 20-25K to go before it's done. I just randomly introduced psychotically aggression changelings. And my main character hasn't even hit half way on the "collect ramdon items to prevent doom" stakes...

First ever proper NaNoWriMo write-in and I wrote 1637 words in the first 45 minutes and over a 1000 in the second 45 minutes. Along with the bus ride to work and the laptop during lunch hour I'm now at 18145 words in total.

That feels like a really good start to my NaNo novel. But then I guess I'd be a bit more confident if I knew quite where it was going next...

So a slightly weird thing happened to me yesterday. As part of NaNoWriMo I found a local write-in that was happening up at Alexandra Palace which is a comfortably 30 minutes walking distance from my house.

Locally known as Ally Pally it's a huge glass and stone complex on a hill where the BBC used to signal boost from, and maybe even still do - I'm not sure. I saw the Afghan Whigs play there earlier this year so I know the way from my house.



Anyway I walk up there, and it's bright but there's plenty of dark clouds threatening rain. A nip in the air but a nice day for a walk all the same even if parts of that hill are fricking steep.

Because there's supposed to be a write-in happening there. Meet at 12.30 at the ice rink, said the forum, and we'll be in the cafe-bar. So I was at the ice rink for 12.30, in fact I was there for 12.20 and I went on through to the Ice-cafe (as it was called) and there's a kid's birthday party happening and no laptops.

Huh.

So I ask around and it turns out there's a bar at the other end of the complex. So I trundle along (it's BIG complex) and go into the Bar-Kitchen and again, no laptops.

I check with the bar staff and they say there's another cafe out past one of the car parks, and I walk down the hill to check it out but it turns out to be really quite a distance and anyway it's called the Grove Cafe, so it's definitely not the cafe-bar. I talk to a security guard and she tells me of a fourth cafe (4 cafes!) over by the boating lake. I have to pass the bar-kitchen and the ice-cafe to get back there so I check on the way and still no laptops. I make it to the cafe by the lake and it's literally empty - not only are there no laptops, there's no people.

I'm a bit lost at this point, so I post on the Nano forum and also on Twitter, but get no response. I check with the husband, agreeing to meet him in the coffee shop underneath his gym, and wander down to it. But when I say wander what I really mean is 45 minute walk through crowded shopping streets because Ally Pally to Manor House - 3 tubes stops and no small distance.

At this point I'm a little bitter - have just 2 hours wandering around an English Heritage monument and NOT WRITING but I suppose my laptop in its nice laptop case did get a day out. 

So I finally make it to the Costa (a big UK chain) and despite the nip in the air I have a lemonade because I'm just too damn hot from all the walking and I notice, over in the corner, at the table which is the perfect height for working on a laptop a girl working on a laptop with a NaNoWriMo sticker on it.

I go across, introduce myself and it turns out she's one of the MLs for London. We have a nice chat and she clues me in to several local writing things - a bookshop turning publisher and a local writers group - and I finally get to add to my word count.

Only 600 words but then I'm only there an hour before the husband comes down from gym and then we go on with our day. So in the end despite not finding a the write-in I was looking for, I did in fact, find a write-in where none existed.

5000+ words on the first day of NaNoWriMo.

Admittedly I did have the day off and spent most of either writing or procrastinating about writing.

But all in all I'd call it a good start.

Posted via LiveJournal app for iPhone.

It's the 29th of October and DEAR GOD I want it to be November already so I can start NaNoWriMo.

I spent the weekend reading a Kindle book on the history of the names of London underground stations and NOW I WANT TO WRITE. I have ideas for words on paper and waiting for the month to turn over is incredibly tedius.

Ahem.

In other news, all good thoughts, hopes and wishes to everyone over there on the Atlantic coast of North America. This storm looks freaking evil so you all stay safe.

This morning I finally finished my spell check of the novel and then, before I could doubt myself, I sent it off to the Harper Voyager digital submission portal.

Now it's all done I'm a little nervous that I didn't spend enough time on the covering letter and synopsis but you know what, if I hadn't had done it this morning I think I might not have done it at all.

So there's that.

Having a lazy weekend, with the exception of yesterday afternoon where the husband and I went into town for 30th birthday drinks (likely my last 30th birthday party in this friend group - wow now we're all *old*) at Wahaca on Charlotte Street where we ate Mexican street food and I was introduced to Mezcal (or possibly Mexcal?) a kind of proto-tequila you drink with a spicy tomato chaser.

The birthday girl did this really cool thing where she made party bags for the entire group which included chocolate, homemade badges, seeds, fossilized shark teeth (!) and temporary tattoos. So we all ended up getting truly trampily tatted with tats on necks, arses and in my case boobs. I got a real kick out of it, but when I woke up this morning I was worried because tomorrow night I'm shooting video at a pretty high class awards evening and all my party dresses would reveal said fake tattoo. So I had to scrub it off with nail polish remover this morning. Shame.

I've recently been getting very into Veronica Mars - bought all 3 season boxsets, but from a dodgy Amazon UK seller which meant that the box art and episode descriptions are in German, even if the DVDs are in English. But a third of the price of the English language box art so I'm not too bothered. I'm halfway through the 3rd season currently and am kind of dreading the end. I know the season doesn't end with Veronica and Logan together - I've read too much fix-it fix to know that, and I know there's 3 storylines in the season and I've just seen 2 of them, so there are so few episodes left...I like it too much to want to get to the end, but I really want to see the episodes.

Catch 22.

Today I'm also spell-checking my way through the second half of the book ready to submit for the Harper Voyager no-agent-submission - though I'm a little concerned any monies are royalties only, no advance payment. But still better some but none.

So I just printed the novel I've been working on out in advance of the Pitch day I'm going to on Saturday.

The damn thing is 209 pages long. I had to find a special large bulldog clip to hold the pages together.

I mean... Wow.

Remember that I've only ever read it on my Kindle so you never really get a sense of length, and even though it's just under 70K for word count, I read 50K fanfics for fun so it never really seemed that long.

But guys, I just killed a tree printing it.

Possibly even two trees.

hey all, so I watched the first season of Veronica Mars this weekend and I am a convert.

AND I NEED FIC.

Anyone got any good recs? I've already worked my way through  back catalogue - anything else out there?

Three nights in a row I've had elaborate movie style bad dreams. Three nights in a row my husband has been in LA and I never sleep well when he's not around.

Night 1: the Tsunami
This started out as a kinda buddy movie thing with a hero and heroine (who was sort of me but then very not) having to work together to get to a beach before a tsunami hit. now if that doesn't make sense to you, don't worry because it didn't make a great deal of sense to me either. My oh so logical brain tried its best to come up with solutions for how being on the beach would save them from the giant wave but they (or at least she) kept drowning, so my brain rewound time and made it so they had to climb a mountain instead. Much more logical. I assume there had to be an element of lucid dreaming with this one because I can remember thinking "no that would kill them they need to get up high" before the dream changed.

Night 2: zombie rage/possessed people
There were work drinks earlier that evening so I think this started with my brain replaying the events of the day. Then the people in the office stopped and their eyes turned black (ala X-files & Supernatural but behaviour was more Croatoan virus than demonic possession) and started attacking each other. And then the dream was all trying to get away/trying to get home in a London filled with rage zombies with black eyes and horrible grins. And I never got very far. So my brain kept rewinding and replaying and I was caught or trapped in a variety of different ways, none of which ended well.

Night 3: foreign prison & torture
Husband and I are overseas somewhere like China with rigid state laws and a language I have no knowledge of. We're trying to get into a concert and are advised to go around the back and say we're with catering. We do this and run into some friendly cops who have me remove my bag/coat and put all my belongings into Husband's bag. Then they have him touch some money. Then we are separated and a friendly police officer informs me Husband is to be arrested for money laundering or carrying more cash than is legal and I'm being done as a nonperson because I'm not carrying my papers anymore, husband is. I try to call out to husband but he's too far away to hear me and I know I'm not going to see him again for a very long time and I panic. I'm allowed a phone call and manage to tell family what has happened but they're on the otherside of the world and so we're arrested and imprisoned. Then timeline gets screwy as are conditions in prison, some torture, some solitary confinement and all I can do is worry that neither husband nor I are strong enough to get through it.

My brain is a fucked up place, filing me with dread over these imaginary scenarios and walking me up in the middle of the night half panicked thinking that they have come true.

Posted via LiveJournal app for iPhone.

So today I'm going to a funeral, which sucks on a number of levels.

Firstly it's a family funeral for a relative I haven't seen in ten years despite the fact we live in the same city, so there's guilt.

Then it's the fact that she, who was a moderately large part of my childhood, seems to have spent a lot of the past few years alone and may have actually died alone, following years/months of demetia, suspected TB and Pneumonia, so there's fear of ending up like that.

And finally, it's the fact it's a funeral - in the past 12 months the number of funerals I've been to is now higher than the number of weddings.  In fact I've only been to 1 wedding this year and that's practically unheard of for me. I suppose Christenings (or more likely given my crowd, non-religious naming ceremonies) will kick in at some point soon given how many people we knnow are pregnant or hangin' with newborns, but still. Have I really entered that stage of life where funerals are more numerous as weddings?

I know this whole post is probably making me seem very cold. And I do feel loss - it's just been such a long time since I saw my Great Aunt - ironically enough, at another funeral, that of my grandmother - that I'm really having trouble dealing with the day.

It's 10 am on a Sunday and I've been up since 6.

My husband has just left for the airport. There's a birthday BBQ for a friend happening but it's not til 4. I have ideas I want to work on, but I don't like the idea of spending all day on the laptop on the kitchen table, but I'm down to my last £20 for the month and going out to a coffee shop to work will eat into that.

Especially as wifi is free at home.

So what to do, what to do.  I finished a latest draft of my novel yesterday morning. It's something beyond a second draft - the first draft was written in NaNoWriMo last year - but it doesn't quite feel like a third draft.  Even though I suppose it is.  The second draft's changes were primarily in the middle and the beginning of the manuscript, the third draft's changes were all about the end.  

Maybe I should call this draft 2.5.  Drafts 2 and 3 combined show changes to the entire story.

Draft 2.5 it is.  Anyway, the husband has been bundled off to the airport with it downloaded onto my kindle to provide feedback on his return.  And also to see if he would like a kindle of his own.  I'll have to make do with the app on my phone for now.

I have some ideas for a sequel.  Nothing concrete but a few things I could work on. But should I work on them here or elsewhere?

Or should I get out my semi-new sewing machine and make that damn pillow I've been planning to make for weeks? I could make on the perfect size to be a lift for my laptop, ease this crick in my neck. 

Or do I go to the cinema?

It's a strange thing about being married. You forget what it is to do things on your own. When faced with a day without your partner, the time stretches ahead, begging to be filled, and all you can do is prevaricate. 

Still I can't make up my mind. I hope something occurs to me soon or I'll lose all this time to DVDs or reading my way through AO3. And I really would like to do something meaningful with this day I have to myself.

So. I bought a laptop.

WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!

It's the first laptop I've ever bought and has only really been bought because the desktop PC in the house is old and malfuncting and the EeePC netbook (Alfie) I used to use cannot cope with Google Docs which is where I do most of my writing these days.  And the Tablet I asked for and was given for my birthday is fine for editing on but crappy to actually write on.

It's an 11.6 inch HP laptop.  A refurbished one that had an additional 15% discount on it that dropped the price by 30% against that of a new one.  And I recently sold some stuff on ebay that covered 2/3rd of the price.  BONUS.

I've asked to have it delivered to the office and I CAN'T WAIT for it to get here!

So i just went to Italy.  Which is, as you might expect, stunning beautiful.

Here's a few photos I took with my phone of Sorrento:


The main square in Sorrento - Piazza Tasso


Watching the sun go down as we walked up the cliff steps from the Port Wednesday night...


The view from the bus stop near our villa...

I'd been to Naples & Sorrento before just under a decade ago so I thought I knew what I was in for... but those hills and roads and Roman monuments were more taxing than I remembered... and they killed my favourite boots 3 days in!


Farewell beloved boots. You served me well for 2 years but I had to leave you in Sorrento. I will miss you always (or until I have enough cash for new boots).

Been a while since I updated so perhaps I should cover the past few months in bullet points.
  • There was work related stress as the company lost the contract to produce the brand on which I work, which led to three months of Am I staying/Am I going? which is not a hassle free environment.  Now it's all sorted out but boy it took its time getting there
  • I have been on a bit of a exercise & diet kick for the past month and as a result have rediscovered my waist and bought a few sundresses to show it off.  Sadly have not managed to lose a single pound despite losing bulk so can't decide if this is a win or not...
  • Went to South Africa in April for 2 weeks on air-miles that the hubby collected by being jetting around the world to play video games (it's a hard life), though the airport tax (that we had to pay regardless) was still 800 quid - huh just realised I'm writing this on a US mac and there's no pound sign, awkward - was a lovely sunny time for us, even if the in-laws all thought it was freezing
  • It has been freezing in London all through April and most of May until last Monday when abruptly the sun was turned on and we've all been suffering from dehydration & sunstroke ever since.
  • Went to my first ever music festival last night to see the Afghan Whigs at Alexandra Palace - first and only time I've ever seen them as they broke up before I was even aware the band existed, though I have seen Dulli's sequel band the Twilight Singers a few times.  They were brilliant.  They even played 66 which was my wedding first dance (already up on youtube, wow, 11 hour old).  Best gig ever.  And as it was freakishly hot we were able to walk home at midnight and not freeze.
  • I'm working on draft 2 of the NaNoWriMo novel.  It's about 56K long and I think it needs a bit more polishing but I'm generally happy with the way it's going...
  • I saw and loved the Avengers and am now getting my fanfic fix by way of Darcy/Clint & Darcy/Bruce fix-its.  I especially like the ones where #CoulsonsAlive and she's his assistant and has the wowed the world with her admin magic.
  • Am off to Italy this week for a wedding, and then I think I'm done on the international travel for a while - got debts to pay down & money to save.  Am trying to clear both credit cards asap, one of which I'm sure I'll have nixed by the end of the year, but the other'll take longer I'm sure.
And that's about it for now... Happy finally arrived Summer!

It's interesting how the more things change the more they stay the same.

When I was a teenager all the cool girls wore Kickers shoes to school. And it was fashionable to wear long socks and scrunch then down around your ankles so you ended up with 3-4 inches of crumpled sock folds.

These days it seems all the cool school girls still wear Kickers but those long socks are now pulled up, and are so long they look more like woollen stockings - over the knee and everything.

And skirts are - and will forever be - indecently short.

Twenty years and the only thing that seems to have changed is whether your socks are pulled up.

*shakes head in amazement*

Posted via LiveJournal app for iPhone.

Today I walked 4km of my journey home. I thought that was about half the distance but it turns out my commute to work is over 10km.

I guess that explains why the bus is late so often.

I should walk more. I walk quite a lot anyway but I should walk more. I'm over more than I should be on my calorie counting app and I'm not losing any weight. Walking more could help.

But then I walked at least 6km on Saturday, down to Hackney for drinks out, and probably another 2km or so on Sunday, walking up to Wood Green to run errands.

Everyone said my metabolism would slow down once I got past 30. It never occurred to me it would be such an obvious change.

Posted via LiveJournal app for iPhone.

Today felt like a very long day. I had to be in by 8 which really means 7.50 so I was at the bus stop for 6.55 only to see the bus disappearing off into the distance. Another one arrived much sooner than the advertised 8 minutes so by 7.01 I was on my way to work.

I stressed all the way in about being late and missing the courier I was coming in early for and also about when I was going to have breakfast only to find that the 7.01 bus apparently has magic powers in that it can defy TFL and make a one hour journey in a mere 45 minutes. I even had time to stop at Pret for my no-milk-in-the-house breakfast of choice - a salmon baguette and a berry smoothie.

So I got to work at 7.55 exactly.

And waited. And waited. And waited.

The courier finally arrived at 8.45 with stories of traffic on London Bridge and the fact the delivery had been booked for 8.30 rather than 8, the later of which was definitely a lie and former something I couldn't give 2 hoots for.

After a few more minor issues (like how to turn on the high powered Mac) I sat down and edited.

And edited. And edited. And edited.

By the deadline six of the seven videos were done. The seventh was scuppered by the fact that nothing was filmed in the first place. Big old oops but thankfully neither my not the company's fault.

I joined digital for an impromptu lunch to celebrate a colleague's three month probation completion at a pub with Meantime LPA on tap. Yum.

Then I went back to the office and edited some more.

The lovely lads from IT took advantage of the fact I was working away from my desk for most of the day so when I finally put in an appearance I discovered I had a shiny new PC. Yay! The old one has been misbehaving recently and there's only so many daily reboots a girl can take.

A bit more footage capturing, a round of rendering, a detour to pack away the camera and I was ready to clock off early, go home and open a bottle of wine.

Which is what I intend to do just as soon as this bus takes me there. And I hope it does because the destination of the damn thing has already changed once and they have a habit of terminating early when faced with traffic jams.

And there's a whole tonne of traffic to jam between here and home.

Posted via LiveJournal app for iPhone.
Connery, people.  I can't believe this is even a question

My undergraduate degree was American Studies and my post-grad was Screenwriting.

I'm a digital manager.  About the closest I get to using my degree is the fact that I learned a lot about the internet when I was at Uni.

I'm currently spending about 45 minutes a day, after I get up but before breakfast, editing my NaNoWriMo Novel into something... better.  So far I'm on page 50 of about 130 and have just had an idea for a couple of insert chapters to increase tension. 

But I still think the damn thing is too short.

It's an urban fantasy, the genre made popular by Jim Butcher, Charlaine Harris, Kelley Armstrong etc, and I really have no idea how long one of those should be.  Does anyone have any guidance?  Would 75,000 words be about right?  Currently it's about 51,000, so obviously I need to grow it a bit, but how much?

Anyone?  Anyone?  Bueller?

Gakked from
Originally posted by at The fiasco continues

ACTA in a Nutshell –

What is ACTA?  ACTA is the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement. A new intellectual property enforcement treaty being negotiated by the United States, the European Community, Switzerland, and Japan, with Australia, the Republic of Korea, New Zealand, Mexico, Jordan, Morocco, Singapore, the United Arab Emirates, and Canada recently announcing that they will join in as well.

Why should you care about ACTA? Initial reports indicate that the treaty will have a very broad scope and will involve new tools targeting “Internet distribution and information technology.”

What is the goal of ACTA? Reportedly the goal is to create new legal standards of intellectual property enforcement, as well as increased international cooperation, an example of which would be an increase in information sharing between signatory countries’ law enforcement agencies.

Essential ACTA Resources - 

  • Read more about ACTA here: ACTA Fact Sheet
  • Read the authentic version of the ACTA text as of 15 April 2011, as finalized by participating countries here: ACTA Finalized Text
  • Follow the history of the treaty’s formation here: ACTA history
  • Read letters from U.S. Senator Ron Wyden wherein he challenges the constitutionality of ACTA: Letter 1 | Letter 2 | Read the Administration’s Response to Wyden’s First Letter here: Response
  • Watch a short informative video on ACTA: ACTA Video
  • Watch a lulzy video on ACTA: Lulzy Video

Say NO to ACTA. It is essential to spread awareness and get the word out on ACTA.

Via Tumblr

Originally posted by at Say No to ACTA
(taken from , originally posted on )

If you're from the UK and you believe in freedom of speech and an uncensored interenet, you really need to sign this petition. There are others floating about, but that particular one is the best way to ensure that your voice gets heard. It's hosted on the directgov website and addresses parliament directly. If it gets more than 100,000 signatures, it becomes eligible for discussion in the House of Commons.

Everyone's been getting so worked up over SOPA -- and rightly so -- that ACTA seems to have slipped under the radar. This is hugely problematic, because ACTA is a similar bill, but it has the potential to be far more damaging than SOPA ever could be.

Some people seem to have this misconception that ACTA is the 'European SOPA', but that simply isn't true. It's a global treaty, and it's already been signed by eight countries, including the US, Japan, New Zealand and Singapore. Europe votes on Thursday. If they vote 'no', the bill will have to be taken back to the drawing board and reformulated, which should buy us some time at the very least.

If you think this doesn't affect you, you're wrong. If ACTA passes, it could well signal the end of the internet as we know it, and that isn't an exaggeration. It's not just about watching movies and television online. If ACTA passes, sites like YouTube, Livejournal, Tumblr, Twitter, Facebook and even Google and Wikipedia could become impossible to maintain. ACTA would allow ISPs to monitor your net activity and cut off internet access for your entire household if one person is suspected of breaching copyright. Think Big Brother is Watching. I don't think I need to emphasise just how damaging it can be to be without internet access in this day and age, when we rely so heavily on technology.

It's not only bloggers and fandom that would be affected, either. Small businesses, independent film-makers and unsigned musicians who have previously found their niche online would also suffer hugely, and would be at risk of being bullied into submission by Hollywood and multinational corporations under accusations of copyright infringement. All those artists who found fame by uploading covers of songs to YouTube would never have had the opportunity to do so under ACTA, as those cover versions would be prohibited.

I know the internet has its problems, but to my mind it's the single greatest invention to come out of modern times, and it would be an absolute travesty if we were to lose that now. From a personal point of view, I can't even put into words how important this is to me. I've met some of my closest friends through the internet and online fandom, people whom I would likely never have met without it, and it's given me this amazing social support system. I don't want that to end here, and I want to preserve it for future generations so that they can have the same experience and opportunities I've been given through my online interactions.

I know that opinions on the seriousness of copyright infringement and online piracy vary wildly, but that isn't really the point. Internet giants such as Google are opposed to this bill, and it's pretty safe to say that they're not in favour of copyright infringment, as anyone who's ever had a fanvid taken down from YouTube will be painfully aware. Whatever your stance on copyright, this isn't the way to go about dealing with it. This is dangerous legislation that impeaches on some of our most basic human rights, such as the right to privacy and freedom of speech.

So if you're from the UK, please, please sign the petition. If you hail from elsewhere in the world, there may well be similar movements in your own country, but I think the most effective thing anybody can do right now is to keep talking about this. Talk about it on Livejournal, on Twitter, on Tumblr, on Facebook, and anywhere else you can think of. Make sure this issue is never far from people's minds. The internet is an amazingly powerful tool: let's utilise it while we still have the chance.

Please repost and spread the word :)

SAY NO TO ACTA!

Posted via LiveJournal app for iPhone.

White Christmas

BBC2 show it ever year on Christmas Eve and I always watch it - even when it's on at an odd time.  To me it's when Christmas starts properly.

and I watched Mr Smith goes to Washington this weekend and were completely and utterly delighted by it. I put it on the rental list out of a combination of a long term admiration of Jimmy Stewart and the fact the film is continually listed as a classic. Plus US politics is kinda like catnip to me.

Needless to say, we loved it, but as soon as it was done, I just had to watch its spiritual successor - "The Stackhouse Filibuster" episode of The West Wing.

But once we start watching The West Wing we rarely stop and so now is watching the rest of season 2 from TSF onwards. These were always done of my favourite episodes of the show but in thinking about this I thought I should make a definitive list of my favourite eps to see if I can remember them all in one sitting.

And so, in no particular order:

"The Stackhouse Filibuster" - because everything about it is lovely. The senior staff writing emails home, Donna figuring it all out, Bartlet's grandfather speech, and George Coe as Stackhouse himself, who was so memorable in this role they brought him back in season 3 as a third party candidate.

"The Supremes" - the only part of season 5 worth watching. William Fitchner and Glenn Close verbally sparring, bonus Robert Piccardo, Donna's parents' cats. "Don't try to keep up." Classic. (My only niggle is that the staff seem to have all forgotten Mendoza, the judge they got on the court in Season 1 - one reference is all it would have taken guys)

"17 people" - in his script book Sorkin describes this one as a play, but it's the kind of episode I've always liked - the quiet after hours episode when it's just the key characters and nothing happens. Stuff does happen here but it's all understated - Toby finds out about the MS, we get more insight into Josh & Donna, Ainsley provides a very irritating reading of the ERA, but it's still a very quiet ep. Perfectly understated.

"Mr Willis of Ohio" - my favourite episode of season one, though it's a close run against "The crackpots and these women," which we will get to shortly. Thinking about it now I guess it's the first TWW successor to Mr Smith but it's different in many ways. It's one man can make a difference but it's also how the argument very rarely matters anymore. Also the senior staff play poker. And that's just a win for me on several levels. I don't even mind Mandy for once.

"The crackpots and these women" - the wolf, the aliens, the NSC card. Ave Maria and that first glimpse into why Josh is just so driven and socially inept. Plus despite all the heartbreaking news it's very funny, and it's the first time Charlie meets Zoe.

"In the shadow of two gunman" - how the gang all got together. Perfect backstories all. Plus Josh & Sam and Josh & Donna.

"Bartlet for America" - Leo McGarry and the hearings, his lawyer being kickass, Cliff ceasing to be creepy and annoying and threatening to "wait in the tall grass" for the republican senator orchestrating the whole thing. John Spencer earning an Emmy and then some.

"Debate camp" - if only for Sam's Bartlet impression. And the flashbacks to the senior staff all nervous in their new jobs. And Toby. Poor Toby.

"lockdown" - when Donna realises she has to get out, Bartlet's new secretary reveals herself to be a crash shark and it was all a drill explanation, only to then reveal it was someone trying to kill Charlie. Wow. Bonus Reed Diamond too which is always fun.

The episode in season 7 where Josh and Donna finally kiss. I can't remember the name but I'll google it when I get to work. It's just perfect - especially their frustration in the obstacles thrown in their way. We waited 7 years and it finally happened.

I'm sure I'll remember more as soon as I post this, so I expect to be updating it several times today, but for now, that's all I've got.

So I wrote a novel.  50,000+ words of it for NaNoWriMo.

I've saved it as a html so I can read it on my kindle and decide what to do with it.  I already know I need to do some serious culling of the 2 penultimate chapters and have some extra interlude-y bits to add in.

But seriously.  I just wrote a novel in a month.

I rock.

So I'm 6400 words into NaNoWriMo 2011 and I am liking where's it going so far.

A stroke of inspiration about a red herring bad guy resulted in me planning out 3 extra chapters last night but even with that I'm only at 15 chapters in total and the 2 and a bit I've written already are 6400 words. So I'm a little worried I might get to 40,000 words and run out of story...

But I guess we'll see.

So this weekend was about family fun, real ale, alarmingly competitive board games and pumpkin carvings.

But I only have instagram pics of that last one...

I'm going to try my hand at NaNoWriMo this year. And I'm going to do it properly.

In past years I've used it to motivate myself for screenwriting and used it like a second Script Frenzy but this year I'm going to jump in on prose. Which is terrifying.

I haven't written prose, properly, for years. Occasional fanfics aside (none of which topped 3000 words anyway) I haven't written propose since I was a teenager.

That's s long time ago.

So I have a character. I have my very own urban fantasy world. I have a few ideas.

What I don't have is a plot.

So I've downloaded a ton of free books of fairy tales and folklore onto the kindle in the name of research and I've got 7 days to come up with something.

I hope inspiration strikes soon

(Also it cannot be said too much how much j love half term. My morning bus is now a pleasant place to be with all the school kids sleeping in at home)

Today it is so cold I am sitting in the side of the bus with heating*. Winter hasn't even begun yet.

*why exactly only one side of the bus has heating is something I have never been able to figure out. But at least it is another seasonal cue for those without calendars. In Summer I (and most sensible people) sit in the left where there is no heating and also no glare from the rising sun on the way to work. In Winter I sit on the right, where there is one below seat row of air heaters but I will spend the next 3 months shielding my eyes from low flying sunlight.

On the positive side has just landed at Heathrow and has brought me gloves back from NYC. As New York gets substantially colder than London but always looks so damn fashionable I am very hopeful he may have found the elusive perfect glove - one that is both stylish and warm. He says he found a pair matching that description in Bloomingdales. I can't wait.

Originally posted by at Mississippi Personhood Amendment
Originally posted by at Mississippi Personhood Amendment
Originally posted by at Mississippi Personhood Amendment
Okay, so I don't usually do this, but this is an issue near and dear to me and this is getting very little no attention in the mainstream media.

Mississippi is voting on November 8th on whether to pass Amendment 26, the "Personhood Amendment". This amendment would grant fertilized eggs and fetuses personhood status.

Putting aside the contentious issue of abortion, this would effectively outlaw birth control and criminalize women who have miscarriages. This is not a good thing.

Jackson Women's Health Organization is the only place women can get abortions in the entire state, and they are trying to launch a grassroots movement against this amendment. This doesn't just apply to Mississippi, though, as Personhood USA, the group that introduced this amendment, is trying to introduce identical amendments in all 50 states.

What's more, in Mississippi, this amendment is expected to pass. It even has Mississippi Democrats, including the Attorney General, Jim Hood, backing it.

What to do?

- Read up on it. Wake Up, Mississippi is the home of the grassroots effort to fight this amendment. Daily Kos also has a thorough story on it.

- If you can afford it, you can donate at the site's link.

- You can contact the Democratic National Committee to see why more of our representatives aren't speaking out against this.

- Like this Facebook page to help spread awareness.

Posted via LiveJournal app for iPhone.

I had what could be described as a very stylish weekend in London.  Generally and I tend towards hermit crabs in this city of ours, only venturing out to places we know that are near at hand, but this weekend was different.

We started on Friday with drinks at the Pembury in Hackney, which is if not my favourite pub in London, then definitely on the top five list.  It's a laid back pub with a very bar-like feel and a huge array of independent beer on tap and very few branded drinks.  It's not the cheapest palce ever but you pretty much get what you pay for and the food is pretty decent.  We were meeting a friend there and before long two more showed up, so we had quite an evening of it, then made our way back home on the overground train.

Saturday started early with several errands to run in the morning.  My work colleagues back in March gave me two tickets to Vinopolis as a 30th birthday present, and as March was six months ago, the tickets were about to expire!  So I booked us in for tastings from 2pm, in order for us to grab some food from Borough Market before committing to some serious drinking.

Despite past experience which has generally ended up with us both pretty sloshed within 20 minutes, the wine tasting didn't hit too hard - three premium tastings at 25ml each, and six standard tastings of the same.  So really it's only actually about 225ml of wine in total, which less than a large glass of wine in a bar.  Admittedly, last time we were there with DoctorSis and her other half and the tasting tickets includes Champagne, Absinthe, Beer and Rum in addition to the vino.  But we were happy with out 9 tasting tickets (and a Bombay Sapphire cocktail) and were sober enough to choose a few bottles to come home with us (all from the £7.99 or less section of the store, which bodes well for our budget).

We wandered across London Bridge with a vague idea of making our way up to Shoreditch for a cocktail, but instead ended up in Spitalfields market, where I drank margueritas and ate tapas while nursed one beer and knocked back two tequila shots.  Tired, and by then, a little drunk, we made our way home via overground train and then watched Pandorum on DVD and drank one of new bottles of wine.

Sunday was another early start, but this time it was about Hyde Park and boating on the Serpentine.  Or at least a boat on the Serpentine - a solar powered boat...
There we and 36 other people celebrated a friend's 40th.  They'd rented out the entire boat, we sipped buzz fizz and ate bacon sandwiches and marvelled in how green and environmentally friendly we were on the solar boat - at least until a little petrol powered boat made three tips between the dock and us delivering, seperately, a carafe of coffee, a load of coffee cups and finally taking the empty carafe back to port. 

We sailed for an hour and half which was lovely, then made our way back to their nearby flat where we all drank too many drinks of too many types and nibbled on an array of picnic food.

Home via tube and bus.

I should also say I spent Sunday in my new dress from Seattle which makes me look very girly and curvy and completely hides how huge my tummy is looking these days.  I would have taken pictures but the camera was completely drained of battery, and unfortunately the shop does not yet have a website so I can't link you.

All in all a lovely weekend - and one of the first for a long time when we saw more of London then just a local neigbourhood.

It's August.

Let me just say that again - it's August.

Is this year on speed or something?  I mean seriously - I only turned 30, like, yesterday and that's already 5 months ago!  5 months!  Well 4 and a bit I suppose as it's only just August and my birthday is late March BUT STILL.

London seems to have finally noticed it's located in the Northern Hemisphere in the Summer months and has let some sunshine out to play.  So much so that I left the house on both days this weekend and on one of them I didn't even take a coat.  Those who know me will know this is a phenomenal thing for me.  I always take a coat.  Admittedly sometimes it's a very thin, almost non-existent jacket but I still always have a coat with me, or - more likely in the Summer months - hanging over the strap of my handbag or stuffed into a shopping bag.

But yes, Sunday was warm enough and bright enough for me to venture outside sans coat.

At which point I went to a cinema to see Captain America and immediately froze as the air conditioning appeared to have been set to compensate for the surface of the sun. 

I have to say I really enjoyed Captain America -  and I said afterwards we felt it's the second best Marvel studios so far (we consider Iron Man as the best so far).  We especially enjoyed the throwaway line that suggested this was all taking place at the same time as either the Raiders of the Lost Arc or Last Crusade and it was only because Hitler was too busy in the desert that the Red Skull was able to undermine and extricate the good weapons away from the Nazis.

Bucky's death was pretty heart-rending too.  Though I loved Neal McDonough as Dum Dum Duggan and the rest of the ethnically diverse POWs in Cap's gang.  It dealt pretty well with Cap's journey - Chris Evan's transformation was bloody impressive though I could see the LOTR-style forced perspective in a few scenes.  And the bookended sequences transplanting him to the modern world worked well too. 

I immediately had to go home and start reading my Ultimates back issues, before getting distracted onto a Stargate Atlantis DVD rewatch in honour of Jason Momoa who I was particularly impressed with in Game of Thrones and can't wait to see in the new Conan film.

Also there was the post-credit Avengers tease, which I'm not kidding 90% of the cinema audience stayed for.  Usually it's us and one other obsessive person but for the Avengers trailer, everyone stayed.  I think I need to find it online so I can get a better sense of it, but from the 2 minutes I saw yesterday, it'll be the movie of next Summer and I can't wait to see it.

Today has been a strange food day so far - I skipped exercise as I had to do the ESTA for next's month trip across the pond.  So instead of cereal I ate the three pieces of chicken and stuffing in the sandwich pack, half a pack of cherry tomatoes, a one day old jam doughnut, half a pack of blueberries and a chocolate biscuit.

I'm not sure whether it's all healthy or unhealthy but my stomach is certainly confused.

has a habit of anthropomorphising things.

Which is normal I suppose if we're talking stuffed toys or figurines or something like that, but somewhat less normal when we're talking bedside lamps.

Seriously, he once convinced me to keep an old beside lamp I hadn't used for years by playing with its adjustable neck and making it look sad.  Seriously.

He does this and then I have guilt and don't throw things out.  This is why our house is FULL of crap.  We don't throw things out - he's just too good at making me feel guilt about the feelings of inanimate objects.

So this is why I had to be sneaky when I threw out the old kettle.  Or at least, I had to do it when he wasn't in the room. Straight into the rubbish with broken kettle - you served us well for like 5 year but I really hate drinking scale in my tea so you have to go.

Because that kettle is D.E.D. dead and I really really didn't want to have to find shelf space for it because   thinks it's funny I worry about the emotional state of my kitchen appliances.

Which I don't, obviously.  It's just that he's a particularly good puppeteer.

Today is my last Monday at my current job.  I finish here on Wednesday and then am off to pastures new for next Monday.

In honour however of 3 years of ups and downs and crazy rebrand projects and website upgrades and health and safety madness I have tweeted the following:


I made reference to this in a flist locked post about 9 months back.  Then it was stressful and scary and the only way to not go insane.  Now I look upon it fondly, knowing that everyone else saw it as nothing more than a joke, and that we got through that project with no actual bloodshed, no matter how bad things got on occasion.

Spent the weekend with DoctorSis and her new man.  They arrived late on Friday night, by which time both and I were both passed out asleep on the sofa.  He at least had the excuse of extreme jet lag and exhaustion resulting from a week at E3.  All I can say is he looked so peaceful I couldn't prevent the zs.

So the original plan had been to do the London Monopoly board, but some creative googling on Friday revealed that the damn thing is 15 miles long and with the circle and district lines down for most of the weekend I didn't like our chances of making it round in one day.  So instead we suggested the Islington/Highbury pub crawl.

We started in Angel at Cuba Libre which is my favourite London tapas place.  Annoyingly the tapas menu has slightly changed and the happy hour cocktail prices have gone up, but it still remains pretty good value with lovely food so that was fine.  Mojito, marguerita and 4 plates of tapas later we were making our way up Upper Street.

Our initial choices of that US themed bar that sells Brooklyn Ale that I can never remember the name of was closed, so we mooched along to the Vineyard in search of Savannah only to find it was no longer on the menu.  Dammit.  That disappointment was followed by both the Albert and Pearl and 25 Canonbury being closed.  Not to be disuaded from our course, we descended upon the Sampler and tasted many wines both good and not so good and  was so intent upon buying a bottle of the Wild Sauvignion that we had to take the last one out of the window display!

On to the Alwynne, which is one of my favourite bars in London where we drank Pimms and Buffalo Trace bourbon (seperately, not together) in the conservatory and nibbled on rice crackers.  Next stop was La fromagerie in Highbury where we picked up 3 very nice cheeses and some charcoal crackers and then on to my favourite wine store in London, Highbury Vintners.  They've just added a tasting zone so that worked and as ever their suggestions for both wine to go with cheese and wine to be drunk by itself were excellent.

Our next and final stop was the Woodbine, where we stayed for 2 rounds (Blue Moon lager is especially nice) and some Thai food (which was fine but repeated on me a bit later), then we moseyed on home via tube and taxi and played a cut throat game of scrabble along with cheese and wine.  A few video games followed (including the wonderfully traumatic Dead Space) and then as we were all falling asleep on sofa, chair and floor, it was time for bed.

Much wine and spirits drunk, cheese, thai and tapas devoured and good company had be all.  A very very good Saturday if I do say so myself...
This weekend I weeded the garden...

So I'm feeling pretty accomplished at the moment.

Last night I visited a friend in the hospital, did a quick shop, bought and repotted a tub each of mint and parsley, spritzed the weeds in the garden with weedkiller and watered the plants.  I also put away all of the laundry and the clean dishes and washed up the pans.  This morning I set the slow cooker going with a casserole for tonight (that meat has to be eaten up) and I have a box lunch with me that's leftovers from the triple batch of tomato and sausage rice I made yesterday morning.

Tonight I may paint the kitchen and watch Castle.

I can has organisation.

Onward bound again - I have a NewJob that starts on the 20th June - leaving what is now OldJob on the 15th.  

Life can be so very strange, I was just reading through the back catalogue here and seeing NewJob, NewJob 2.0, NewJob 2.5 - all of that seems like such a very long time ago.

This time I'm moving on and moving up - proper step forward in this strung together list of employments I call a career.  I wasn't completely looking for it, but in the past few weeks when I was negotiating (Negotiating!  Hark at 'er!) for the best deal possible and consider jobs both old and new it became clear to me that I really did need to move on.

I leave behind me a final salary pension (an act I'm sure will cause any accountants out there actual physical pain) and a whole bushel of friends I hope to be able to keep in touch with.  I'm not generally brilliant at keeping in touch but we shall see - the glorious interweb does make it easier.

I've got pre-new-job apprehension at the moment (What if? What if? What if?) but on the whole I'm doing okay.  And it's enough of a pay rise I'll be able to clear my immediate loan and credit card debt pretty sharpish which is nice.   I'd be using up almost all of this year's holiday to be able to get Stateside for a wedding but I think I'm okay.  It's a whole new thing now, and as much as I wonder and worry, I think this is the right thing to do, and I hope it works out.
